Movie: Are You There God? It's Me, Margaret.
Review: it is always really special to see films take kids’ feelings seriously.

I think this film fulfilled my unspoken desire for what *could be* Miyazaki’s final film — that it would feel both familiar and totally novel. There were so many instances where I’d see something Spirited Away-ish, Howl’s-ish, etc; but in the end it still felt innovative in form and substance. Some really incredible animation — the wartime scenes in the beginning felt particularly new for Miyazaki, actually a bit Takahata-ish — and I loved seeing this film’s iterations of his…
i am calling for a moratorium on any casting decisions where Thomasin plays someone with a very specific regional accent
a great movie for people who are really fucking stressed

I really enjoyed this — the subtlety of every performance, the brilliance of the writing, the silliness of the court room scenes. Anyone who’s struggled against their own inertia will find a lot to identify with in both partners, who are frustrated and beaten down by difficult elements of their life; trying and failing to address their failures or accommodate someone else’s; aspiring to hope and love amid it all. I think this is where the film excels the most…
idk why I went into this movie thinking Val Kilmer was gonna be this egregiously sinister antagonist when he’s actually just a more safety-minded, conscientious pilot than Cruise?

Deeply watchable and fun. Felt the constraints of Mattel’s editorial control strongly, both in the 2015-era gender consciousness and in the treacly last 30 mins featuring the Barbie founder, but w/e — not gonna think about it too much! Had a good time.
